questions.text: All of the following myotomes contribute to the diaphragm muscles except?
Which structure on the anterior abdominal wall is likely to be defective in degenerative malformation of the transversalis fascia during development ?

options.label: D
options.text: Sac of a direct inguinal hernia

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical facts is true about the stomach?

options.label: A
options.text: Lymph from the superior two third of the stomach drains into the supra-pancreatic nodes.

options.label: B
options.text: All lymphatic drainage from the stomach drains through the celiac nodes.

options.label: C
options.text: The gastric branches of the vagus are given at the greater curve.

options.label: D
options.text: The lower esophageal sphincter is supplied by the nerves of Latarjet.

questions.correct_answer: B. All lymphatic drainage from the stomach drains through the celiac nodes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with burning in the mid-epigastric region, a sour taste in his mouth after meals, and a red tongue-like mucosa observed during endoscopy with biopsy showing columnar metaplasia. At what distance from the gastroesophageal junction is the Z line seen in this condition?

A 34-year-old male presents with shoulder pain, neck stiffness, headache, raised blood pressure, and constipation. An X-ray revealed extra bone growth on the cervical vertebrae , and an MRI showed a pinched nerve. Regarding the structure involved, which statement is not true in the context of the patient's pathology?
In which phase of meiosis do Leptotene and Pachytene occur?
Which among the following is a remnant of notochord?
Which tongue muscle is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve?
All of the following structures are attached to the lateral condyle of the femur, except?
questions.explanation:
Structures

                          Sites of attachment on femur

Capsule

Along a line 1 cm above the articular margins of medial (as well lateral) condyle.

Fibular collateral ligament

Lateral surface of lateral condyle presents a prominence called lateral epicondyle

Anterior cruciate ligament

Posterior part of the medial surface of the lateral condyle of the femur.

Popliteus

A groove below and behind the lateral epicondyle of the femur

Lateral head of the gastrocnemius

Arises from smooth impression above and behind the lateral epicondyle.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents unconscious after a roadside accident. Examination reveals contralateral lower limb weakness. Occlusion of the artery supplying the marked area will lead to all the symptoms mentioned below EXCEPT?

A 62-year-old woman presented with involuntary rhythmic movements of her hands for the past 3 months, worse at rest and affecting both hands, with a history of chronic liver disease, hypertension, and peripheral artery disease. W hat is the most likely diagnosis based on examination findings and the structure involved in the patient's pathology, as shown in the provided image?

A 22-year-old girl comes to the emergency department with an incised wound in the front of her wrist. The patient has had a history of untreated depression for the last 5 years. The patient is unable to oppose the tips of the little finger and the thumb. Which of the following nerves is/are involved?

A 4-year-old boy is brought to the hospital by his parents due to a high-grade fever, swollen hands and feet, and a rash over his body. The fever developed five days ago and did not respond to paracetamol. On physical examination, there is cervical lymphadenopathy, swollen, erythematous palms, and soles with peeling skin. The eyes are red and injected . Identify the correct statement regarding the most likely diagnosis.

options.label: A
options.text: It is an acute febrile mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: It is not a common vasculitic disorder in childhood

options.label: C
options.text: In the acute stage, o nly aspirin is used in the treatment

options.label: D
options.text: In the convalescent stage, b oth IVIG and aspirin are used in the treatment

questions.correct_answer: A. It is an acute febrile mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for an evaluation of developmental delays and mental retardation. The patient has a history of multiple seizure-like episodes. His parents also describe that the boy often appears restless and constantly moving. He also experiences tremors. On examination, the boy has a musty body odour and blue eyes. If the incidence of the disease this patient suffers from in the general population is 1 in 10,000. How often is the disease transmitted?

An infant is evaluated in the nursery. The infant was born by vaginal delivery about an hour before. The mother has a history of preeclampsia during pregnancy. The mother had a vesicular rash over her body two days ago, but the rash spread towards the body. APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The boy weighs 3 kg . The vital signs are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate step for this infant?

options.label: D
options.text: Test for the presence of antibody

questions.correct_answer: C. Passive immunization with monoclonal antibody

questions.text: A 1-year-old male is brought to the paediatric outpatient department by his mother for his routine evaluation. She is concerned about the patient’s height. Physical examination reveals that the patient’s weight is tripled, and the length has increased by 50% since birth. Which of the following gives the exact time for the height to become twice as long as it was at birth?
questions.explanation:
Age

Height (cm)

Birth

50

1 year

75

2 years

90

4 years

100

12 years

150

questions.text: A 2-year-old female child is brought to the pediatric OPD by her mother, who was normal at birth having normal early development . However, she now presents with microcephaly, regression of acquired language and motor milestones , and abnormal stereotypic hand-wringing movements . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the hospital with complaints of fever associated with retro-orbital pain . The patient gives a typical history of a mosquito bite that presents with white dots. On examination, the patient presents with narrow pulse pressure with cold extremities . Which of the following clinical features are seen in the condition, as mentioned earlier?

A child was admitted to the pediatric department Upon improvement in her health, she was making cooing sounds and laughing aloud. However, she was not able to sit. She was not able to engage in mirror play and did not have any stranger anxiety. While the senior doctor was taking a clinical class for the final-year students, one of them asked, What is the developmental age of this child?
questions.explanation:
Spontaneous smile

Neonatal period

Recognizes mother

3 months

Hand regard

Begins at 12 weeks and ends at 20 weeks

Smiles at a mirror image

5 months

Vocalizes or jumps while looking at a mirror image

6 months

Object permanence

9 months

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to urology OPD by his father with a complaint of increased penile size and excessive pubic hair . Upon further investigation, his three younger brothers have no history of similar issues. On examination, bilateral testicular enlargement is evident. A comprehensive hormonal evaluation showed an elevated serum testosterone value (4.0 nmol/L) and a prepubertal gonadotropin hormone value. What is the most common cause of peripheral precocious puberty in males ?

At 38 weeks of pregnancy, a 32-year-old lady with poorly controlled diabetes delivered a healthy child. Pancreatic islets in the neonate would be expected to demonstrate which of the following morphological responses to injury resulting from maternal hyperglycemia during pregnancy?

A 30-year-old guy has a persistent cough, a low-grade fever, night sweats, and overall malaise. An X-ray of the chest reveals abnormalities "compatible with a Ghon complex." Acid-fast bacilli are seen in sputum culture. Which of the following pathologic alterations would be most likely to be found in this patient's hilar lymph nodes?

With more than 1 in 10 new cancer diagnoses yearly, breast cancer is the most common cancer in women. It is the second most frequent cancer-related death among women worldwide. Breast cancer is connected to:

A 46-year-old man is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of pain in the lower limbs upon walking and blackening of the tips of his fingers. He has an 80-pack-year history of smoking. Laboratory investigations show haemoglobin of 15 g/dL, WBC of 8,300/μL, cholesterol of 223 mg/dL, and fasting blood sugar of 97 mg/dL. Tests for antinuclear antibodies are negative. Biopsy of the affected area (shown in the image) shows intraluminal thrombi in medium-sized arteries and inflammation extending from arteries to neighbouring veins and nerves. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 54-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to acute, severe left-sided chest pain for 20 minutes. She was admitted to the hospital 3 weeks ago for acute myocardial infarction. Her blood pressure is 80/40mmHg, and her pulse is 100/min. Physical examination reveals an anxious person with elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) and reduced heart sounds. Appropriate measures are taken, but the patient fails to survive. An autopsy is carried out to find the cause of death. The image below shows the changes in the patient's heart: Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient?

A 45-year-old patient presented with neurological deficits and seizures. Imaging showed a lesion in the temporal lobe. Biopsy was taken from the lesion, and neural tissue was sent for histological examination (microscopy shown below). Based on the characteristic histological features, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with a high-grade fever and neck pain. He was suffering from an upper respiratory tract infection 2 weeks ago. On examination, his thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and tender. Laboratory analysis shows elevated leukocytes and ESR. After a thorough clinical evaluation, de Quervain's thyroiditis is diagnosed. Which of the following is the feature of de-Quervain thyroiditis?

options.label: A
options.text: In the early phase, follicles are disrupted and replaced by neutrophils forming microabscesses

options.label: B
options.text: Orphan Annie nuclei are seen on histology

options.label: C
options.text: Bacterial infection is a trigger in most patients

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most common cause of painful, multinodular thyroid

questions.correct_answer: A. In the early phase, follicles are disrupted and replaced by neutrophils forming microabscesses

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the hospital with burning upper abdominal pain for 2 months. Pain is burning and relieves with antacids or food. Moreover, she has a history of hyperparathyroidism. Subsequently, her laboratory tests show microcytic and hypochromic anaemia, and her gastroscopy shows a bleeding mucosal defect in the antrum. Which of the following statements best characterises the pathogenesis of upper abdominal pain in this patient?

An 8-year-old boy with newly developed diabetes mellitus died on the way to the hospital after a car accident. He had a long-standing history of diabetes that is poorly controlled with medication. If an autopsy is performed, which of the following findings would be least likely to be consistent with type II diabetes mellitus?

A 55-year-old male comes to the outdoor patient department with complaints of severe muscle weakness and drooping eyelids. He states that his symptoms worsen with repetitive movements but resolve after a short rest. A chest X-ray reveals an anterior mediastinal mass. A biopsy of this mass would most likely reveal which of the following pathologic changes?

A 34-year-old man who is a known case of Diabetes Mellitus Type 1 presents to the physician’s clinic with a 5-month history of weakness and fatigue. There is no history of drug or alcohol abuse. His nutritional history is good, as he eats a healthy balanced diet. On physical examination, he looks pale. The rest of his systemic examination is unremarkable. His complete blood count (CBC) shows megaloblastic anaemia and a normal reticulocyte count. Further laboratory investigations reveal vitamin B12 deficiency. Anaemia in this patient is most likely caused by which of the following?

A 28-year-old patient presented with a complaint of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. Histopathological examination showed arborization and pseudo-invasion. Gene responsible for the condition is LKB1/STK11. A colonoscopy revealed multiple polyps. What is the most common site of polyp formation in this condition?

A 41-year-old male patient was admitted to the surgical ward with advanced colorectal cancer. A left colectomy was performed. The specimen was sent for histopathology, which suggested poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Family history was taken in detail, which showed 6 members (one of them was a first-degree relative) with colon cancer. Their malignancy was diagnosed before 40 years of age. Doctors suspect an inherited syndrome in the family. Which of the following would be the most likely diagnosis if the patient also had multiple osteomas, desmoid tumours, and supernumerary teeth?

A 28-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine physical exam. The patient has no chronic medical conditions. The patient has had multiple sexual partners and takes oral contraceptives. She was previously uninsured and has not seen a physician for several years. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), her pulse is 67/min, and her blood pressure is 123/71 mmHg. A Pap smear is performed, and the results are notable for high-grade squamous epithelial dysplasia. Subsequent colposcopy with biopsy confirms the presence of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) grade II. Which of the following best describes the portion of the cervix that is affected in this patient?

A 2-hour-old newborn male is examined in the nursery. The boy was born to a 42-year-old G2 P1 female at 39 weeks gestation. She did not receive any prenatal screening or assessment. Apgar Scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The child is vitally stable and breathing normally. After a complete examination, the paediatrician suggests a diagnosis of Down syndrome. Which of the following Is a feature of Down syndrome?

A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the outpatient department with a history of mental confusion and unsteady gait for four days. He also gives a history of worsening night vision for two months. Lab investigations reveal extremely low levels of cholesterol at 40mg/dl. The peripheral blood smear reveals spur cells with irregularly spaced blunt-tipped spicules. The morphologic abnormalities demonstrated in this blood smear are most likely to be associated with which of the following conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: Abnormal spectrin in red cell membranes

questions.text: A 28-year-old male athlete training for a marathon race is advised by his coach to increase his carbohydrate intake after the workout. The carbohydrate uptake will help to build up glycogen stores in the muscles. Glycogen synthase is the main enzyme involved in glycogen synthesis in the muscles. Which of the following acts as an activator of muscle glycogen synthase?

Match the organelle with its biochemical marker: Organelle Biochemical Marker 1. Lysosomes a. rRNA 2. Peroxisomes b. Galactosyl Transferase 3. Endoplasmic Reticulum c. Catalase 4. Ribosomes d. Lactate Dehydrogenase e. Acid Phosphatase f. Glucose-6-Phosphatase

Cell Organelle

Marker

  • Mitochondria

Insulin is responsible for hypoglycemic action after a meal and acts through the combined activities of transporters GLUT-2 and GLUT-4. Which of the following DOES NOT depend on insulin for glucose uptake:

A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of high fever and erythema on his right forearm with an abscess formation. The culture sensitivity report from the pus shows strains of staphylococcus aureus. Increased activity of the enzyme hyaluronidase is found in the patient's serum. Which of the following compounds in this patient's serum confirm a connective tissue pathology?

A 3-month-old infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly and failure to thrive. A liver biopsy reveals glycogen with an abnormal, amylopectin-like structure, as shown below: Which of the following enzymes would most likely be deficient?

questions.text: What is the accurate definition of isoenzymes and their significance in diagnosing tissue or organ injury or disease in organs like the liver, heart, and muscle?

options.label: A
options.text: Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze a different reaction

options.label: B
options.text: Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same reaction

options.label: C
options.text: Forms of the different enzymes that catalyze a different reaction

options.label: D
options.text: Forms of the different enzymes that catalyze the same reaction

questions.correct_answer: B. Forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same reaction

questions.text: A 55-year-old female comes to the outdoor patient department complaining of lethargy, headache, and inability to concentrate. On investigation, her serum ammonia levels are high. After detailed laboratory investigations, a probable diagnosis of Urea cycle disorder is made. Which of the following drugs can be used to reduce ammonia levels in this patient?

A 28-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with elevated cholesterol levels of 325 mg/dL on a routine checkup. His father consistently had high levels of cholesterol throughout his life and eventually died of a heart attack at the age of 42. He was prescribed lovastatin , and his cholesterol levels dropped to 170 mg/dL . The most likely reason for the elevated cholesterol in this patient is due to a mutation in which one of the following proteins?
questions.explanation:
Deficiency/ Defect Disease
MTP deficiency Abetalipoproteinemia
LCAT deficiency Fish-eye disease (partial deficiency), Norum disease (complete deficiency)
Lipoprotein lipase deficiency Familial hyperchylomicronemia

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency day after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He has multiple lacerations to his upper extremities and sustained an open fracture to his lower extremity. Initial CBC reveals white blood cells count at 22 x 10 3 /µl, and subsequent complete blood count analysis after 5 hours reveals the white blood cells count at 7 x 10 3 /µl . Which of the following is the r eason for the increase in white blood cell count on the initial blood report?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow

options.label: B
options.text: Release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

questions.correct_answer: B. Release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

questions.text: The absorption of different substances occurs through different transport processes. The transporter that carries glucose and galactose into the enterocyte is the sodium-dependent hexose transporter, known more formally as SGLUT-1. Which of the following methods aids in Glucose absorption from the gut?
Where in the gastrointestinal tract does the majority of iron absorption occur?

A researcher is investigating how folic acid is metabolized in the body. It is an essential and water-soluble vitamin in leafy green vegetables. It is absorbed in the proximal jejunum by which of the following mechanism?

How does the implanted pacemaker address the underlying mechanism associated with intermittent shortness of breath, palpitations, sinus bradycardia, and sinus pauses in a patient experiencing lightheadedness?

options.label: A
options.text: By generating a If (funny current) induced fast depolarisation

options.label: C
options.text: An inward calcium current through T-channels

options.label: D
options.text: An inward calcium current through L-channels

questions.correct_answer: C. An inward calcium current through T-channels

questions.text: An investigator is developing a drug. He develops a new drug that decreases the number of voltage-gated potassium channels in cardiac muscle cell membranes. As a result, less potassium outflux will occur in the myocardium in response to the mechanism of action of this drug. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug on the myocardial action potential?

In a physiology seminar, a group of medical students gives a presentation on renal physiology. They elaborate on the process of filtration and reabsorption. Filtration is the mass movement of water and solutes from plasma to the renal tubule that occurs in the renal corpuscle. About 20% of the plasma volume passing through the glomerulus at any given time is filtered. This means that the kidneys filter about 180 liters of fluid daily. Thus, the entire plasma volume (about 3 liters) is filtered 60 times daily. A substance is present in a concentration of 2 mg% in the afferent arteriole and 0 mg% in the efferent. A true statement about the substance is?

options.label: A
options.text: It is freely filtered at the glomerulus

options.label: D
options.text: Impermeable in the loop of Henle

questions.correct_answer: A. It is freely filtered at the glomerulus

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of hypocalcemia?

options.label: A
options.text: Numbness and tingling of circumoral region

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperactive tendon reflexes and positive Chvostek's sign

options.label: C
options.text: Shortening of Q-T interval in ECG

questions.correct_answer: C. Shortening of Q-T interval in ECG

questions.text: During the menstrual cycle , which of the following is the main source of estrogen?
Baricitinib is used for treatment of r heumatoid arthritis . Which of the following is true about this drug?

options.label: B
options.text: Also approved for use in moderate to severe Crohn’s disease

options.label: D
options.text: Dose reduction is not required in renal and hepatic impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following is an Incorrect example of antimicrobial drug synergism?

options.label: A
options.text: Amphotericin B and flucytosine in cryptococcal meningitis

options.label: B
options.text: Carbenicillin and gentamicin in pseudomonal infections

options.label: C
options.text: Penicillin and tetracycline in bacterial meningitis

options.label: D
options.text: Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole in coliform infections

questions.correct_answer: C. Penicillin and tetracycline in bacterial meningitis

questions.text: A pregnant female presents to you after coming in contact with a family member who has been admitted for Meningococcal meningitis . Which of the following drugs will you give for Prophylaxis ?
questions.explanation:
Persons requiring antimicrobial Prophylaxis following Neisseria meningitidis exposure
  • Household members
  • Roommates or intimate contacts
  • Childcare centre workers
  • Persons directly exposed to respiratory or oral secretions (kissing, mouth-mouth resuscitation, endotracheal intubation/management)
  • Persons seated next to an affected person for > 8 hours (airline travellers)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a potential adverse effect of fluoroquinolones?
Which of the following statements about fluconazole is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It is highly effective in the treatment of aspergillosis

options.label: B
options.text: It does not penetrate the blood-brain barrier

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with an increased incidence of adverse events compared to Ketoconazole.

options.label: D
options.text: It inhibits the demethylation of lanosterol

questions.correct_answer: D. It inhibits the demethylation of lanosterol

questions.text: Which antimalarial agent is most commonly associated with acute hemolytic reaction in patients with glucose-6- phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency?

A 50-year-old man presented with multiple joint pains and morning stiffness lasting for an hour. He has been prescribed aspirin for pain alleviation. Which of the following statements is true about aspirin ?

options.label: A
options.text: In an afebrile patient acute overdose of aspirin produces hypothermia

options.label: B
options.text: Aspirin suppresses flushing associated with a large dose of nicotinic acid

options.label: C
options.text: Aspirin therapy prevents granulomatous lesions and cardiac complications of acute rheumatic fever

options.label: D
options.text: Long-term aspirin therapy increases the risk of developing colon cancer

questions.correct_answer: B. Aspirin suppresses flushing associated with a large dose of nicotinic acid

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with diplopia, slurred speech, breathing difficulty, drooping eyelids, and fatigue for 2 weeks , worsening progressively throughout the day and improving with rest. No other abnormalities or chronic illnesses reported. Vital signs stable, with no other physical abnormalities. Doctor prescribed neostigmine over physostigmine. What justifies this drug preference?

options.label: B
options.text: It has a longer duration of action

options.label: C
options.text: It doesn't cross BBB effectively and has no central action

questions.correct_answer: C. It doesn't cross BBB effectively and has no central action

questions.text: A young 22-year-old male presents in an outpatient clinic with the complaint of cough and difficulty breathing while lying down; He was stung by a scorpion while camping. He is diagnosed with hypertension and pulmonary edema due to a scorpion sting . This patient can be best managed by?

A 24-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with complaints of headaches for the past four months. Resting blood pressure is measured at 164/100 mmHg while sitting. From the following, which anti-hypertensive agents must be recommended based on the patient's condition?

A 35-year-old patient presents in the outdoor department with a complaint of headache and anxiety for two days. On examination, he has a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg with other vitals in the normal range. He is a non-compliant hypertensive and has been on metoprolol therapy for the last two years. His echocardiogram shows mild mitral regurgitation with an ejection fraction of 47%. The intern wants to initiate verapamil as a second anti-hypertensive but is told by the consultant to review his prescription. Which of the following is likely to happen with the above combination therapy?
A 29-year-old schizophrenic male, currently under the treatment of Haloperidol , presented with Parkinsonism-like symptoms . Which of the following would you prescribe?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor performance in school for the last year. He has difficulty sitting at his desk, does not follow the teacher's instructions, and frequently blurts out answers in class. He is often sent outside the classroom for failing to work quietly. He also has a history of inattentive spells when talking to his friends. He does not wait for his turn at hockey practice and has difficulty listening to his coach's instructions. His mother reports that he is easily distracted when she speaks to him and often forgets his books at home. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic criteria (according to the DSM-5) [9]

A

Pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity that is inconsistent with the developmental level of the individual

  • Inattention is characterized by ³ 6 of the following in children or ³ 5 of the following in adolescents and and adults (³ 17 years of 
    • Poor attention to details at work/school
    • Difficulty sustaining attention during tasks
    • Does not listen when spoken to directly (e.g. distraction in the absence of an obvious interruption)
    • Inability to complete tasks/instructions at work/school (e.g., easily sidetracked)
    • Struggles to organize tasks/activities (e.g. disorganized work, misses deadlines)
    • Prefers to avoid tasks that require a high amount of mental effort (e.g., homework, preparing reports)
    • Loses things necessary to complete tasks (e.g., stationery, documents)
    • Easily distracted
    • Forgetful (e.g., does not pay bills, does not do homework)
  • Hyperactivity and impulsivity are characterized by ³ 6 of the following in children or ³ 5 of the following and adolescents and adults (³ 17 years of    
    • Fidgets or squirms in seat
    • Often leaves their seat during inappropriate situations (e.g. during meetings or in class)
    • Restless (runs about in inappropriate situations)
    • Unable to carry out tasks quietly
    • Talks excessively
    • Answers questions prematurely or for others
    • Difficulty waiting their turn (e.g. has problems with lines)
    • Interrupts other people (e.g., in conversation, during activities)

B

Several symptoms are present at < 12  years of age.

C

Symptoms are present in ³ 2 settings (e.g., school, home, work). 

D

Symptoms interfere with important levels of functioning (e.g. school, work). 

E

Symptoms are not due to a mental disorder.

Differences between Anterior and Posterior Epistaxis
  Anterior Epistaxis Posterior Epistaxis
Incidence Site More common Less common
Site Mostly from the little's area or anterior part of the lateral wall Mostly from the posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity; often difficult to localize the bleeding point
Age Mostly occurs in children or young adults After 40 years of age

Bleeding Usually mild, it can be easily controlled by local pressure or anterior pack Bleeding is severe and requires hospitalization; a postnasal pack is often required

questions.explanation:
Definition Acute Otitis Media (AOM) is a common ear infection that affects the middle ear, characterized by inflammation
  and fluid accumulation behind the eardrum.
Causative Agents Bacterial pathogens: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis
  Viral pathogens: Respiratory syncytial virus, Influenza virus, Rhinovirus, Adenovirus, etc.
Risk Factors - Young age (most common in children aged 6 months to 3 years)
  - Presence of upper respiratory tract infections (common cold)
  - Attendance at daycare or school with increased exposure to germs
  - Exposure to tobacco smoke
  - Bottle-feeding while lying down
Clinical Presentation - Ear pain (otalgia)
  - Hearing loss or decreased hearing (conductive hearing loss)
  - Fever (in some cases)
  - Irritability and fussiness in infants and young children
  - Pulling or tugging at the affected ear (in infants)
Diagnostic Criteria - Medical history and physical examination
  - Otoscopic examination to visualize the tympanic membrane and middle ear
  - Presence of fluid or pus behind the eardrum (effusion)
  - Distinct signs of inflammation, such as redness, bulging, or loss of the light reflex on the eardrum
Treatment - Antibiotics (if bacterial AOM is confirmed or suspected)
  - Pain relief with analgesics or antipyretics (e.g., acetaminophen or ibuprofen)
  - Warm compresses to relieve pain and discomfort
  - Rest and adequate fluid intake to support recovery
  - Observation in selected cases (viral AOM or mild symptoms in older children and adults)
Prevention - Vaccination against bacterial pathogens like pneumococcus and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  - Promoting exclusive breastfeeding to reduce the risk of AOM
  - Avoiding exposure to tobacco smoke, as it increases the risk of AOM in children
  - Practicing good hygiene and handwashing to prevent the spread of infections

questions.explanation:
ACL (Anterior cruciate ligament) PCL-(Posterior cruciate ligament) (stouter ligamentous structure)
  • Intracapsular, extra-synovial
  • Intracapsular, extra-synovial
  • The major stabilizer of the knee stabilizes internal rotation and extension of the tibia on the femur.
  • Limits forward gliding of tibia on femur hyperextension
  • Contributes to lateral stability and limits anterolateral rotation of the tibia on the femur.
  • Injured by the occurrence of excessive movements, which it limits.
  • It limits the backward glide of the tibia on the femur (posterior translation) and checks hyperextension only after the ACL is ruptured.
  • PCL restricts External rotation
  • Injured by high-velocity trauma (‘dash board impact’) with posterior dislocation of the tibia on a flexed knee
  • The posterior cruciate ligament is active in all knee movements.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male, an elderly diabetic patient, is brought to the medical outpatient department by his daughter with complaints of altered mental status, headache, and nasal congestion. He has been suffering from these symptoms for a week now. He is also complaining of blurred vision. On examination, he has facial swelling on one side. On the chest X-ray, cavitary lesions are seen. The doctor orders a fungal screen. The biopsy showed LCB-stained periorbital exudates in severe panophthalmitis with cellulitis and showed obtuse angle branching aseptate and broad hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Name Mucormycosis 
Type Fungal infection caused by Mucorales fungi, commonly belonging to the genera Rhizopus, Mucor, and others
Predisposing Factors - Immunocompromised state (transplant recipients, diabetes, cancer, HIV)- Trauma, burns, surgery
Routes of Infection Inhalation, ingestion, direct inoculation, including wounds and invasive medical procedures
Clinical Forms - Rhinocerebral (head and sinuses)- Pulmonary (lungs)- Cutaneous (skin)- Gastrointestinal
Symptoms - Facial pain, headache, nasal congestion (rhinocerebral)- Cough, chest pain, fever (pulmonary)
  - Skin lesions, ulcers (cutaneous)- Abdominal pain, vomiting (gastrointestinal)
Diagnosis - Clinical presentation- Imaging (CT, MRI)- Biopsy and histopathology- Microscopy
Treatment - Antifungal therapy (amphotericin B)- Surgical debridement of infected tissue- Control of risk factors
Prognosis Mortality rate varies based on the site of infection, underlying conditions, and timely treatment
Prevention - Strict blood sugar control in diabetes patients- Protective measures in high-risk patients
Epidemiology - Rare, but has gained attention due to recent cases during the COVID-19 pandemic

Predisposing factors:

options.label: A
options.text: Most common type of gallstone is mixed

options.text: Black stones are hard and radiolucent

options.label: C
options.text: Brownstones are most common in the gallbladder

options.label: D
options.text: Most common type of gallstone in the Asian population is cholesterol stones

questions.correct_answer: A. Most common type of gallstone is mixed
questions.explanation:
Cholesterol stones Pigmented stones
  • In the USA and Europe, 80% are cholesterol or mixed stones
  • Cholesterol or mixed stones - 51-99% pure cholesterol plus an admixture of calcium salts, bile acids, bile pigments and phospholipids
  • Only 10% of the stones are radiopaque

 

  • Pigmented stones contain <20% of cholesterol and are dark because of the presence of calcium bilirubinate
  • Black stones - Insoluble bilirubin polymer + calcium phosphate + calcium bicarbonate
  • Brown pigment stones- calcium bilirubinate + calcium palmitate + calcium stearate+ cholesterol
  • Pigment stones are often radiopaque
  • β glucuronidase secreted by bacteria that enzymatically cleaves conjugated bilirubin to produce the insoluble unconjugated bilirubin, which then precipitates with calcium, and along with dead bacterial cells, bodies forms soft brownstones in the biliary tree.
  • Brownstones occur due to parasitic infection with Ascaris lumbricoides(roundworm) or Clonorchis sinesis (liver fluke)

questions.text: Certain infectious diseases lead to multisystem involvement. A number of diseases cause atrioventricular nodal block due to the involvement of the cardiac tissue. Which of the following diseases does not cause AV nodal block or any other cardiac complication?
questions.explanation:
Name Cat Scratch Disease (CSD)
Causative Agent Most commonly caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae, which can be transmitted through the scratch or bite of an infected cat.
Epidemiology - CSD is relatively common, especially in areas with a high population of stray or outdoor cats. - Most cases occur in children and young adults.
Clinical Features - Localized lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), often near the site of a cat scratch or bite. - Fever. - Fatigue. - Headache. - Body aches. - Rash (less common).
Diagnosis - Clinical evaluation based on symptoms and a history of cat exposure. - Serologic tests (e.g., enzyme immunoassay) to detect antibodies against Bartonella henselae. - Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to identify the bacterium in tissue or fluid samples.
Treatment - In most cases, CSD is self-limiting, and supportive care (rest, pain relief, and warm compresses for lymph nodes) is sufficient. - Antibiotics (e.g., azithromycin or doxycycline) may be prescribed for severe or persistent cases.
Complications - In rare cases, CSD can lead to more serious complications, such as disseminated infection (infection spread throughout the body), neurologic involvement, or ocular complications.
Prevention - Avoid rough play with cats, especially kittens and strays. - Wash cat scratches or bites promptly with soap and water. - Keep cats indoors to reduce exposure to potential sources of infection.
Prognosis CSD is usually a self-limiting disease with a favorable prognosis, and most patients recover without long-term complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with abnormal menstrual bleeding and a pelvic mass undergoes a hysterectomy. The image shows the gross specimen removed. What is the diagnosis?
In the perspective of the busy life schedule in modern society, the accepted minimum period of sexual cohabitation resulting in no offspring for a couple to be declared infertile is:
questions.explanation:
Male Factor Infertility Issues with the male partner's sperm, including low sperm count, poor motility, abnormal morphology, or azoospermia.
Female Factor Infertility Problems in the female partner's reproductive system, such as ovulation disorders, blocked fallopian tubes, or PCOS.
Unexplained Infertility Infertility without a known cause, even after thorough medical evaluation.
Hormonal Infertility Hormonal imbalances in women that disrupt the normal ovulation process.
Tubal Infertility Blocked or damaged fallopian tubes that prevent sperm from reaching the egg or hinder the fertilized egg's journey.
Uterine Infertility Abnormalities in the uterus, like fibroids or adhesions, that interfere with implantation or pregnancy development.
Cervical Infertility Problems with the cervix, such as thick mucus hindering sperm movement.
Immunological Infertility The body's immune system attacks sperm cells or embryos, preventing pregnancy.
Age-Related Infertility Decline in the quantity and quality of eggs as women age, making conception more challenging.
Lifestyle-Related Infertility Factors like obesity, excessive alcohol consumption, smoking, drug use, and stress can contribute to infertility.

A rural PHC was screening all the neonates of the village for any neonatal disorders. Which of the following is the most common neonatal disorder screened?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The object of screening newborns is primarily to detect infants with treatable genetic, developmental and other abnormalities, and secondarily, to provide their parents with genetic counselling. Most common neonatal disorder to be screened is Neonatal hypothyroidism (NNH). Congenital hypothyroidism leads to serious sequelae, including severe mental retardation, which can be prevented if medical treatment is given within the first 1-2 months of life.
